Preferred Citation Form

The suggested citation for the material is "[item], School of Mathematics records, [series] - Box [box number], From the Shelby White and Leon Levy Archives Center, Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton, NJ, USA."

Return to Table of Contents »

Historical Note

The School of Mathematics was the first School established by the Institute. It has also become the largest. Founding Institute Director Abraham Flexner explained the decision to establish this School first, because mathematics "(1) was fundamental...(2) required the least investment in plant or books... (3) [and there was] greater agreement upon personnel in the field of mathematics than in any other subject.". 1

Mathematician Oswald Veblen, among the close advisers to Flexner, was the first Faculty appointment to the School of Mathematics, effective October 1, 1932. In the fall term of 1933, the School officially began its work in loaned space on the Princeton University campus in Fine Hall, now Jones Hall, with roughly thirty participants, including Faculty and visiting scholars. The promise of establishing a close relationship in both the short- and long-term between mathematicians at the Institute and Princeton University had been a determining factor in locating the Institute in Princeton, New Jersey.

By the beginning of 1935, Veblen had been joined on the School's Faculty by James Alexander, Albert Einstein, Marston Morse, John von Neumann, and Hermann Weyl. Each represented intellectual excellence and diversity in the field of mathematics—though being rooted in the same overall discipline also resulted in essential interconnections and overlap. Some of the early Faculty, von Neumann and Weyl in particular, represented uniquely eclectic approaches. The Faculty was also chosen for their ability to be magnets for other scholars. This would be essential to support the central purpose of the Institute as a haven for short-term independent study. The intellectual climate of the School also fostered more structured opportunities for learning, including seminars and courses. In addition, there were scheduled times for presentations and discussion afforded by the Mathematics Club.

In 1939, the Institute's own campus was established, so that the School was able to move to the new Fuld Hall, retaining only a minor presence in Fine Hall for several more years. Despite the move, as had been hoped, intellectual exchange and collaboration between mathematicians at the Institute and Princeton University remained vital. For roughly the School's first decade, the composition of the Faculty was stable even as a steady stream of scholars came and went. In the late 1940s and 1950s, as the original Faculty members retired or died, new appointments were made -- such as Atle Selberg (1951), Deane Montgomery (1951), Armand Borel (1957), and André Weil (1958) -- that would carry the School through the next several decades.

In the late 1970s, the School looked back over its history and described its work until then as follows: "Reflecting the interests of the permanent Faculty over time, the School has been primarily concerned with five areas broadly understood: topology; analysis and global analysis; Lie groups, algebraic groups, automorphic functions and number theory; algebraic geometry; and logic". 2 In addition to these core areas of study, until the creation of the School of Natural Sciences in 1965, the School of Mathematics did in fact pursue the study of mathematics using an especially wide scope, so that the natural sciences, especially mathematical physics, has been a fundamental part of the intellectual development of the Institute. The two Schools have found it mutually beneficial to continue working cooperatively in the field of mathematical physics—to mention just one area of such collaboration.

While the number of active Faculty in the School of Mathematics has grown only modestly over the years to a total of eight in 2017, appointments have provided occasions to stretch the intellectual scope of the School into fields traditionally less represented by the Faculty. One example was the 1986 appointment of Thomas Spencer, whose work incorporates applied mathematics, whereas the intellectual mainstay of the School has been chiefly in pure mathematics.

In contrast to the number of Faculty, the number of visiting scholars has seen more significant growth over the years. By the 2010s, it was common for the School to invite fifty to sixty scholars per academic year with that number increasing to nearly one-hundred when categories such as short-term visitor and long-term appointments factor in. The School of Mathematics is one of only eight Mathematical Sciences Institutes supported nationwide by the National Science Foundation.

In addition to hosting visiting scholars, the School has historically found other means by which to encourage scholarship in the field of mathematics. Beginning in 1933, , the leading mathematical journal in the United States, began joint publication by the Institute and Princeton University. This collaboration continues through today. In the 1960s, the School established "Special Years," as they are now often called, based upon a "promising" 3 topic intended to attract a nexus of scholars within the School, while continuing to place major emphasis on support of mathematicians studying across the spectrum of the field. The initiative lapsed for a time due to lack of financial resources, but was revived in the 1980s. Examples of Special Years include: Statistical Mechanics and Stochastic Geometry (1997-1998) and Galois Representations and Automorphic Forms (2010-2011). In the early 1980s, the School initiated the Hermann Weyl Lectures, which are presented on an irregular basis. Past presenters of these Lectures, which are published in the , include Clifford Henry Taubes (2002) and János Kollár (2007). The seminars, courses, and other structured learning opportunities established from the earliest days of the School have been continued. An example of seminars are those in theoretical computer science and discrete mathematics. The School's presence in fields related to these disciplines had lapsed since the days of Faculty members Kurt Gödel and John von Neumann. The seminars began on an exploratory basis in the early 1990's, and took firm hold with their success and the appointment to the Faculty of Avi Wigderson in 1999.

The field of mathematics faces systemic challenges in regard to inclusivity. The School has invited women from the beginning, but a program administered by the School directly addresses the hurdles faced by women mathematicians. Established in 1994, the Mentoring Program for Women in Mathematics (renamed, in 2006, the Program for Women and Mathematics) annually hosts women mathematicians, including those at the undergraduate level, for an "intensive 11-day mentoring program." 5 Another program administered by the Institute provides an outlet for those with limited access to the academy. The IAS/Park City Mathematics Program (PCMI), affiliated with the IAS since 1993, has various components that provide opportunities for independent and collective study and includes a three-week residential summer session. A key component of PCMI is the opportunity to build relationships between mathematicians at various stages of their career.

In 1993, there were two new buildings completed on the Institute campus (the first significant construction since 1969). One was the new home of the School of Mathematics. It features seminar rooms and a common room in addition to enough office space to bring most of the School's visiting scholars, Faculty, and staff under one roof. The School has also retained a presence in Fuld Hall, including the Mathematics-Natural Sciences Library. In 1999, the so-called Math Building was rededicated as Simonyi Hall in honor of generous contributions by IAS Trustee Dr. Charles Simonyi to the School of Mathematics.

1 Abraham Flexner, . pp. 359-360 (Simon and Schuster, 1940) 2 3 4 http://pcmi.ias.edu/about/ 5 http://www.math.ias.edu/wam/news

Restriction Note

Administrative records of the Institute are closed for 30 years from the date of creation. Letters of recommendation are closed until both the author and the subject of the recommendation have died.

Return to Table of Contents »

Related Materials

Related Materials

Further information relating to those represented in the Members, Visitors, Assistants series can be found in various locations. For short-term visitors, especially those without files, minimal information can sometimes be found in the School's Faculty Meeting Minutes in the School of Mathematics records. For scholars in the natural sciences before 1965, also see the School of Natural Sciences's People series. For all visiting scholars, files have also been created and maintained by the Director's Office. Within the record group for that office, please see the following series, as appropriate: Members files, Visitors files, and Assistants files. In the rare case that a scholar also served on the Institute's Board of Trustees, the record group for that body may provide additional materials.

For the School in general, the Director's Office: Schools files series will contain some materials both duplicating the School's own records and unique to the collection. The set of Faculty Meeting Minutes originating with the Director's Office is less comprehensive than the set from the School itself, but the folders that include meeting Agendas dating from 1953-1987 are unique.

Return to Table of Contents »

Collection Inventory

Faculty Meeting Minutes 1935-1993 1.0 linear feet

Scope and Contents note

The Faculty Meeting Minutes series is an ongoing series that currently spans the years 1935-1993, with the first meeting held on October 8, 1935, and the last minutes currently available being those for the April 5, 1993, meeting. The series contains final versions of minutes for meetings of the School's Faculty. The series includes a subject index produced for the minutes by the School that was compiled through 1990 minutes.

The minutes most often address School business on matters such as administration and policy, appointment of scholars (including Assistants), and finances. For some meetings, there are attachments of various kinds such as financial overviews, important letters, and reports of the School. These attachments often provide additional insights and details. As the Faculty Meeting Minutes series includes years that precede the establishment of the School of Natural Sciences, information about scholars in those fields can also be found in these minutes.

Though not represented here, drafts of minutes, often labeled "Rough" at the top of the page, were circulated by the School for review by the Faculty. Agendas were also sent in advance of the meetings.

Arrangement note

The Faculty Meeting Minutes series is in chronological order. The pages are also numbered consecutively by the School beginning with the first set of minutes. Interspersed, however, there are documents that don't follow the overall numerical order of the pages. These pages most often relate to the meeting date which they follow and are attachments to the minutes for that meeting.

Members, Visitors, Assistants 20.0 linear feet

Scope and Contents note

The Members, Visitors, Assistants series is an ongoing series currently divided into two time spans: 1933-1977 and 1978-1983. These date spans are general rules of thumb, but actual dates for the materials pertaining to any individual scholar may vary. Most of these individuals were affiliated with the Institute as Members, but the series also includes Visitors and Assistants. All three of these categories describe scholars affiliated with the School for at least one of the two terms of the regular academic year.

Documentation in the files includes application forms, letters of inquiry, letters of recommendation, and other supporting materials related to applications, financial matters, and scholarly work, including academic accomplishments and goals for the duration of the scholar's association with the Institute. Within the 1933-1977 datespan, there are also a few files for organizations or institutions (e.g., IAS Electronic Computer Project, National Research Council, New York City High School, Rockefeller Foundation).

It is important to note that the series does not represent everyone affiliated with the School during this period. First, the files of physicists and other natural scientists affiliated with the Institute prior to the establishment of the School of Natural Sciences in 1966 are found in that School's "People" series. Second, until 2010, the School did not retain files for people who came solely for less than an academic term or outside the regular academic year, often noted in other School documentation as "short-term visitors" or "summer visitors". (The School did, however, retain materials pertaining to all visits, regardless of duration, for any individual with at least one full academic term visit.) Lastly, since the School keeps together all materials relating to a scholar, files for scholars with affiliations both pre- and post-1983 remain on file with the School of Mathematics at the time of writing.

Arrangement note

Within each time span, the materials are in alphabetical order by last name, topic, or organization. As the School keeps together all materials relating to a single scholar, materials for an individual will be found in the span that includes that scholar's latest date of affiliation with the Institute.
